subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Such a mapping is unattainable, because even uncontroversial English consonants map to more than one IPA sound depending on dialect and on the surrounding
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> But above all this topic really shows the need for a standard mapping of
> QS letters to IPA symbols. I can see that different people pronounce
> words differently, but if each QS letter does not mean a very specific
> sound, which should map to IPA, then the alphabet becomes ambiguous and
> somewhat meaningless.

Such a mapping is unattainable, because even uncontroversial English
consonants map to more than one IPA sound depending on dialect and on the
surrounding sounds. English "p" is an aspirated unvoiced labial stop,
except after "s" where it loses aspiration; English "b" is an unaspirated
labial stop, but it can be voiced or voiceless or varying freely between
the two.

--
